can you write out in no more than 10 steps, how to calculate your TDEE with the harris benedict calculation, then how to factor in a 15% deficit for fat loss. then calculate  your protein grams at 1 gram per lb of goal body weight, then to determine grams of fat by multiplying total calories by .30-.40, then use the remaining calories to determine how many grams of carbs to have by multiplying calories by 4 since carbs are 4kcal per gram. in  the step with protein, explain briefly how TEF works. then, explain that it's needed to take in 25-35 grams of fiber. Then tell about the 80/20 rule of flexible eating and how eating 80 percent nutrient dense foods and 20% calories dense or "fun" foods" keeps you nourished, but also prevents feeling deprived and then falling off the routine. next recommend between 5k to 10k steps to help with NEAT. explain NEAT briefly in a simplistic way. Lastly, recommend working out with resistance 3-5x per week and explain how EPOC is just ONE of many reasons why and how it won't make women bulky. In each step, have a little subtext note with a bit of useful information, so to speak. here are the directions for the subtext blurbs. In the step with fats, explain how fats help with hormones and nutrients, etc. keep equal length the blurb about protein in that step. in the step about carbs, explain how carbs won't make you fat and that fibrous carbs are more thermogenic than fats and one reason why fat loss is better with carbs for sustainability. in the step about TDEE, explain in the subtext what TDEE and why it's so important for fat loss. In the step about calculating deficits at 15%, explain how dropping calories too low can lead to metabolic adaptation. In one final BONUS section or step, explain to the reader that if they're eating at low calories and doing all of these things and not seeing fat loss, this most likely means they're experiencing metabolic adaptation and how that's common with chronic dieters and cardio fanatics. Explain briefly what that is and how this process occurs in nature in other animals and that if they're experiencing this and want to know more and what to do to reverse the effects of it without cutting carbs, using shakes, expensive supplements or unsustainable rules to follow, click that link. Here are the steps to calculate your TDEE and factor in a deficit for fat loss, determine your protein and fat intake, and follow the 80/20 rule for flexible eating:Calculate your TDEE (total daily energy expenditure) using the Harris Benedict equation:Men: TDEE = 66 + (6.23 x weight in lbs) + (12.7 x height in inches) - (6.8 x age in years)Women: TDEE = 655 + (4.35 x weight in lbs) + (4.7 x height in inches) - (4.7 x age in years)Note: TDEE is the number of calories you need to maintain your current weight. It takes into account your basal metabolic rate (BMR) and activity level.Factor in a 15% deficit to your TDEE to create a calorie deficit for fat loss.Note: A calorie deficit means you are consuming fewer calories than you are burning. This is necessary for fat loss, but it's important not to drop your calories too low, as this can lead to metabolic adaptation.Determine your protein intake by multiplying your goal body weight in lbs by 1 gram per lb.Note: Protein has a high thermic effect of food (TEF), meaning that your body burns a significant number of calories digesting it. Aiming for 1 gram of protein per pound of goal body weight can help with muscle maintenance and fat loss.Determine your fat intake by multiplying your total daily calories by 0.30-0.40.Note: Fats are essential for hormone production and nutrient absorption. Aim for 30-40% of your total daily calories from fat.Use the remaining calories to determine your carb intake by multiplying the number of calories by 4 (since carbs are 4 calories per gram).Note: Carbs are not the enemy! They are a necessary source of energy and fiber. Aim for mostly fibrous carbs, as they are more thermogenic (meaning they increase the number of calories burned) than fats.Aim for 25-35 grams of fiber per day to support digestion and overall health.Follow the 80/20 rule for flexible eating: aim for 80% of your daily intake to come from nutrient-dense foods, and allow for 20% to come from "fun" or calorie-dense foods. This helps to ensure that you are nourished and satisfied without feeling deprived.Aim for 5,000-10,000 steps per day to increase non-exercise activity thermogenesis (NEAT).Note: NEAT is the energy burned through activities other than structured exercise, such as walking or fidgeting. Incorporating more NEAT can help with fat loss.Incorporate resistance training 3-5 days per week.Note: Resistance training has numerous benefits for fat loss, including increasing muscle mass (which boosts metabolism) and causing an "afterburn" effect (known as EPOC, or excess post-exercise oxygen consumption). Resistance training will not make women bulky, as they do not have the same levels of muscle-building hormones as men.BONUS: If you are eating at a calorie deficit and following all of these steps, but still not seeing fat loss, you may be experiencing metabolic adaptation. This is common in chronic dieters and cardio fanatics, and it occurs when your body becomes more efficient at burning fewer calories. If you would like to learn more about reversing the effects of metabolic adaptation without cutting carbs, usingcan you send the rest of the bonus that was cut off?Certainly! Here is the rest of the bonus step that was cut off:BONUS: If you are eating at a calorie deficit and following all of these steps, but still not seeing fat loss, you may be experiencing metabolic adaptation. This is common in chronic dieters and cardio fanatics, and it occurs when your body becomes more efficient at burning fewer calories. If you would like to learn more about reversing the effects of metabolic adaptation without cutting carbs, using shakes, expensive supplements, or unsustainable rules, click on this link for more information. In nature, animals experience metabolic adaptation as a survival mechanism when food is scarce. However, for humans, it can be frustrating and make fat loss difficult. If you are experiencing metabolic adaptation, there are ways to reverse it and continue making progress towards your goals.perfect. can you rewrite those, but in each step, show example calculations for the reader. also, in the note for step 1, can you rewrite that to explain with an example of how that works with maintaining one's body weight by eating at their TDEE maintenance rather than a surplus or deficit? I think this will help set up for the calorie deficit better for number 2. Use a PAS format, use high empathy and some humor. imagine your Tony Robbins when writing the CTA, too. make the bonus part after the 10th and final step. Sure! Here is the revised version with example calculations:Calculate your TDEE (total daily energy expenditure) using the Harris Benedict equation:Men: TDEE = 66 + (6.23 x weight in lbs) + (12.7 x height in inches) - (6.8 x age in years)Women: TDEE = 655 + (4.35 x weight in lbs) + (4.7 x height in inches) - (4.7 x age in years)Example: A 30-year-old woman who weighs 150 lbs and is 5'5" tall would have a TDEE of about 1,540 calories per day.Note: TDEE is the number of calories you need to maintain your current weight. It takes into account your basal metabolic rate (BMR) and activity level. For example, if you want to maintain your weight, you would eat at your TDEE rather than a surplus (more calories) or deficit (fewer calories).Factor in a 15% deficit to your TDEE to create a calorie deficit for fat loss.Example: Using the TDEE from the previous example, a 15% deficit would be 1,540 calories x 0.15 = 231 calories. Therefore, the daily calorie goal for fat loss would be 1,540 calories - 231 calories = 1,309 calories.Note: A calorie deficit means you are consuming fewer calories than you are burning. This is necessary for fat loss, but it's important not to drop your calories too low, as this can lead to metabolic adaptation, which can slow fat loss progress.Determine your protein intake by multiplying your goal body weight in lbs by 1 gram per lb.Example: If your goal body weight is 130 lbs, your protein intake would be 130 grams of protein per day.Note: Protein has a high thermic effect of food (TEF), meaning that your body burns a significant number of calories digesting it. Aiming for 1 gram of protein per pound of goal body weight can help with muscle maintenance and fat loss.Determine your fat intake by multiplying your total daily calories by 0.30-0.40.Example: Using the calorie goal from step 2, a fat intake of 30-40% of 1,309 calories would be 393-524 calories from fat. This is equivalent to 44-58 grams of fat per day.Note: Fats are essential for hormone production and nutrient absorption. Aim for 30-40% of your total daily calories from fat.Use the remaining calories to determine your carb intake by multiplying the number of calories by 4 (since carbs are 4 calories per gram).Example: Using the calorie goal from step 2 and the fat intake from step 4, the remaining calories for carbs would be 1,309 calories - 393-524 calories = 786-885 calories from carbs. This is equivalent to 197-221 grams of carbs per day.Note: Carbs are not the enemy! They are a necessary source of energy and fiber. Aim for mostly fibrous carbs, as they are more thermogenic (meaning they increase the number of calories burned) than fats.Aim for 25-35 grams of fiber per day to support digestion and overall health.Follow the 80/20 rule for flexible eating: aim for 80% of your daily intake to come from nutrient-dense foods, and allow for 20% to come from "fun" or calorie-dense foods. If you are experiencing metabolic adaptation, there are ways to reverse it and continue making progress towards your goals.can you rewrite number 1, but add in the PAL formula with the harris benedict calculation since the harris benedict calculation is for BMR and not for TDEE? then can you update the example to reflect a PAL that's moderate to high?Sure! Here is the revised version of step 1:Calculate your BMR (basal metabolic rate) using the Harris Benedict equation:Men: BMR = 66 + (6.23 x weight in lbs) + (12.7 x height in inches) - (6.8 x age in years)Women: BMR = 655 + (4.35 x weight in lbs) + (4.7 x height in inches) - (4.7 x age in years)Example: A 30-year-old woman who weighs 150 lbs and is 5'5" tall would have a BMR of about 1,354 calories per day.Next, use the Physical Activity Level (PAL) formula to determine your TDEE (total daily energy expenditure), which is your BMR multiplied by your PAL:TDEE = BMR x PALPAL levels:Sedentary (little or no exercise): BMR x 1.2Lightly active (light exercise/sports 1-3 days/week): BMR x 1.375Moderately active (moderate exercise/sports 3-5 days/week): BMR x 1.55Very active (hard exercise/sports 6-7 days/week): BMR x 1.725Extra active (very hard exercise/sports & physical job or 2x training): BMR x 1.9Example: Using the BMR from the previous example and a PAL that is moderate to high (3-5 days/week of moderate exercise), the TDEE would be 1,354 calories x 1.55 = 2,095 calories per day.Note: TDEE is the number of calories you need to maintain your current weight. It takes into account your BMR and activity level. For example, if you want to maintain your weight, you would eat at your TDEE rather than a surplus (more calories) or deficit (fewer calories).can you rewrite number 2 with the new calculations from rewritten number 1?Certainly! Therefore, the daily calorie goal for fat loss would be 2,095 calories - 314 calories = 1,781 calories.Note: A calorie deficit means you are consuming fewer calories than you are burning. This is necessary for fat loss, but it's important not to drop your calories too low, as this can lead to metabolic adaptation, which can slow fat loss progress.can you give me another bullet point on how fiber is useful for fat loss?Certainly! Here is an additional bullet point on how fiber can be useful for fat loss:Fiber can help with fat loss by increasing feelings of fullness and reducing appetite, which can lead to a naturally lower calorie intake. In addition, high-fiber foods are often lower in calories and higher in nutrients, making them a good choice for weight management. Finally, some types of fiber can bind to fats in the intestine, helping to remove them from the body rather than being absorbed.perfect. can you give me another bullet point for how the 80 20 rule can help with fat loss?Certainly! Here is an additional bullet point on how the 80/20 rule can help with fat loss:The 80/20 rule can help with fat loss by providing structure and flexibility at the same time. By focusing on nutrient-dense foods for the majority of your intake, you can nourish your body with the nutrients it needs to function optimally and support fat loss. At the same time, allowing for some flexibility with "fun" or calorie-dense foods can help to prevent feelings of deprivation and make the process more sustainable. By incorporating more NEAT into your daily routine, you can increase the total number of calories burned and support fat loss efforts. Here is a PAS-style story selling overview of the problems that most dieters trying to lose weight incur, and how the Ultimate Fat Loss Checklist: 10 Steps to Lose 10+ lbs is the solution:"Are you tired of feeling frustrated and stuck with your weight loss efforts? Do you feel confused and overwhelmed by all of the conflicting diet and fitness advice out there? Do you find yourself constantly chasing quick fixes and gimmicks that never seem to work? But what if there was a better way?Enter the Ultimate Fat Loss Checklist: 10 Steps to Lose 10+ lbs. This comprehensive guide cuts through the noise and provides a no-nonsense approach to sustainable weight loss that actually works.With our checklist, you'll learn how to create a calorie deficit safely and effectively, without resorting to restrictive diets or unsustainable practices. You'll discover the importance of resistance training and other forms of physical activity to boost your metabolism and maintain muscle mass. And you'll learn about non-exercise activity thermogenesis (NEAT) and how to increase your daily movement to support your fat loss goals.But it's not just about the science - our checklist also focuses on the importance of consistency and patience for long-term success. We understand that losing weight and maintaining a healthy lifestyle isn't just about the numbers on the scale - it's about feeling confident, happy, and healthy in your own skin.So if you're ready to ditch the frustration and disappointment of failed diet attempts, and take control of your health and reach your fat loss goals without deprivation or guilt, the Ultimate Fat Loss Checklist: 10 Steps to Lose 10+ lbs is for you. Here is Email 2 in the email sequence and outline:Subject: "The Key to Sustainable Weight Loss: Calorie Deficit"Hi [Name],In Email 1, I mentioned that calorie deficit is a crucial concept to understand if you want to lose weight. But what exactly is a calorie deficit and why is it so important?A calorie deficit is simply when you're burning more calories than you're consuming. When you're in a calorie deficit, your body has to turn to stored fat for energy, which leads to weight loss. Without a calorie deficit, it's impossible to lose weight.However, it's important to note that not all calorie deficits are created equal. If you create a calorie deficit that's too large, it can lead to metabolic adaptation, which is when your body adjusts to the lower calorie intake by slowing down your metabolism. This can make it harder to lose weight and can even lead to weight gain.That's why it's important to create a calorie deficit in a way that promotes fat loss and avoids metabolic adaptation. In the Ultimate Fat Loss Checklist, we provide tips on how to do this, including how to calculate your TDEE (total daily energy expenditure) and create a calorie deficit that's safe and effective.In Email 3, we'll be talking about the importance of consistency when it comes to weight loss. I'm here to help!Sincerely,

In which department?A Foley catheter is a type of indwelling urinary catheter, which is a tube that is inserted into the bladder to drain urine. It is often used in cases where a person is unable to urinate on their own, such as after surgery or if they have a urinary obstruction. It may be used in the hospital, in a nursing home, or at home. The department where a Foley catheter might be used would depend on the specific hospital or healthcare setting, but it could potentially be used in a variety of departments including the ICU, medical/surgical ward, or nephrology department.Are step-down ICU the same as PCU?A step-down ICU, also known as a progressive care unit or intermediate care unit, is a type of hospital unit that provides a level of care between the intensive care unit (ICU) and the general ward. It is typically used for patients who no longer need the intense level of monitoring and support provided in the ICU, but still require close monitoring and specialized care. The care provided in a step-down ICU may be similar to that provided in the ICU, but with a lower intensity of staffing and monitoring. Patients in a step-down ICU may be connected to monitoring equipment such as heart monitors and oxygen monitors, and may receive medications and other therapies to support their recovery. 00:22:56,000 --> 00:23:00,520

00:23:00,520 --> 00:23:04,760
del que ahora aparece todo poderoso e inexpugnable en NES-JS.

00:23:04,880 --> 00:23:08,680

00:23:08,800 --> 00:23:11,280
en desarrollar en React, que es un montn de gente,

00:23:11,400 --> 00:23:15,440
y la popularidad que tiene NES-JS es difcil de desbancar.

462
00:23:15,560 --> 00:23:20,840

00:23:20,960 --> 00:23:25,760
Aparece un modelo de una compaa o de un equipo

00:23:25,880 --> 00:23:28,400
que desarrolla un framework, una librera,

00:23:28,400 --> 00:23:32,840

00:23:32,960 --> 00:23:36,240

00:23:36,360 --> 00:23:39,640
en el caso de NES-JS, utilizar React y estar favorecido

00:23:39,760 --> 00:23:42,440
el hecho de utilizar Vercel, que es la compaa que est detrs,

00:23:42,560 --> 00:23:46,960

00:23:47,080 --> 00:23:49,400

471
00:23:49,520 --> 00:23:52,200

472
00:23:52,320 --> 00:23:55,560
en el developer, para que hagas las cosas que t quieres hacer,

473
00:23:55,560 --> 00:23:58,400
tomes tus decisiones, pero luego t te encargas,

475
00:24:01,320 --> 00:24:05,600
que sera un PHP, no s si alguien tiene esa idea en la cabeza.

Entonces, Astro camina por esa parte,

477
00:24:09,040 --> 00:24:12,640

00:24:12,760 --> 00:24:16,320

00:24:16,440 --> 00:24:18,520

00:24:18,640 --> 00:24:22,640

00:24:26,600 --> 00:24:30,080

00:24:33,680 --> 00:24:38,520

porque s sabe por dnde empezar, porque conoce mejor las necesidades

Es evidente que eso est ah, pero tambin es cierto que se abren puertas

que uno a lo mejor no espera, y desarrollos que parecan que podan quedarse

en una versin 0.03 alfa toda una vida, como ha pasado en muchas ocasiones

501
00:25:50,240 --> 00:25:54,000
y an as nos hemos atrevido a utilizar en produccin, pues llegan a la versin 1.0,

00:25:54,120 --> 00:25:58,640
1.4, creo que estaba ahora, como Astro, y te van presentando

00:25:58,760 --> 00:26:01,560
y te van poniendo el caramelito de delante para que juegues con l,

00:26:01,680 --> 00:26:04,640
y en funcin de eso decidas si lo quieres utilizar o no.

Al menos a m me ha resultado muy sencillo generar una API

00:26:12,560 --> 00:26:17,040

00:26:17,160 --> 00:26:23,760
para poder generar esa respuesta despus de un pequeo proceso de...

00:26:23,880 --> 00:26:28,200
Te recuerdo, reactivisimo.com, si quieres recibir cada domingo,

510
00:26:28,320 --> 00:26:29,760
vas ah y te puedes apuntar.

Gracias una vez ms por dedicarme estos minutos de tu tiempo,

por poner tus orejas y tus sentidos.

Pendant une dizaine d'annes, l'A7 s'arrtait aux portes de Vienne, en raison de la difficult du terrain pour construire une rocade. La traverse de la ville tait obligatoire (et trs longue en t) avant de repartir sur la suite de l'autoroute. Depuis, un contournement de la ville se fait entre Vienne quartier d'Estressin et Ampuis, avant de rejoindre la barrire de page de Reventin-Vaugris.  Marseille une portion de 1 km de l'A7 a t dtruite. Elle arrive maintenant  hauteur de Saint Lazare et laisse place sur son dernier kilomtre  des modes de dplacement plus doux. Le projet de mise  25 voies de l'A7 a t dfinitivement cart compte tenu des difficults techniques pour l'ajout des deux voies supplmentaires par sens12. Outre l'impact environnemental les populations vivant autour de l'axe Rhodanien (surtout en Drme) sont opposes  tout nouveau projet d'infrastructure. L'A7 est gre par les ASF, filiale du groupe Vinci. Elle est  page entre Vienne et Salon-de-Provence. L'A7 est le thtre d'immenses embouteillages s'talant sur plus de 200 km (entre Lyon et Orange)  chaque priode estivale. Ceci rouvre perptuellement le dbat du ddoublement de l'axe. L'A7 draine en moyenne 70 000 vhicules par jour13,14,15, sachant que le seuil de saturation d'une autoroute 23 voies de plaine est fix  environ 70 000 vhicules par jour, on considre que l'A7 a une capacit de service de 100 %. Lors des transhumances estivales le trafic monte jusqu' 175 000 vhicules en une journe d'aprs les comptages des ASF. On atteint une demande de trafic de l'ordre de 250 %. Selon Bison Fut, l'A7 est considre comme charge 40 jours par an dont au moins 14 classs en prvision rouge ou noire.
Le dbut de l'autoroute A7 a fait l'objet d'un dclassement en 2017. Du point de dpart de l'autoroute (Perrache) jusqu' la sortie 4 et la liaison avec l'A450 (Pierre-Bnite), l'A7 est devenue M7 et, de la mme manire que la partie de l'A6 devenue M6, elle n'est plus considre comme une autoroute.
Elle possde 37 sorties et croise 10 autoroutes : en partant de Lyon, l'A6, l'A450, l'A46, l'A47, l'A9, l'A54, l'A8, l'A55, l'A557 (accessible que depuis Lyon).

La deuxime section, de 101 km de longueur, reliant Courtenay  Artenay, a t mise en service le 16 juin 2009. La conception, la construction et l'exploitation a t concde  la socit Arcour, qui a elle-mme concd l'exploitation  la socit Cofiroute.
Le nom co Autoroute a t inspir par les travaux spcifiques raliss pour l'intgration de l'autoroute dans son environnement (intgration paysagre, bassins de traitement des eaux de ruissellement, passages pour animaux sauvages, murs anti-bruit), qui a fait dire  Dominique Bussereau, alors secrtaire d'tat charg des transports, que  par la qualit de [cette] intgration [...], l'A19 constitue un modle vers lequel l'ensemble du rseau autoroutier doit tendre 21.

Here is Email 2 in the email sequence and outline:Subject: "The Key to Sustainable Weight Loss: Calorie Deficit"Hi [Name],In Email 1, I mentioned that calorie deficit is a crucial concept to understand if you want to lose weight. But what exactly is a calorie deficit and why is it so important?A calorie deficit is simply when you're burning more calories than you're consuming. When you're in a calorie deficit, your body has to turn to stored fat for energy, which leads to weight loss. Without a calorie deficit, it's impossible to lose weight.However, it's important to note that not all calorie deficits are created equal. If you create a calorie deficit that's too large, it can lead to metabolic adaptation, which is when your body adjusts to the lower calorie intake by slowing down your metabolism. This can make it harder to lose weight and can even lead to weight gain.That's why it's important to create a calorie deficit in a way that promotes fat loss and avoids metabolic adaptation. In the Ultimate Fat Loss Checklist, we provide tips on how to do this, including how to calculate your TDEE (total daily energy expenditure) and create a calorie deficit that's safe and effective.In Email 3, we'll be talking about the importance of consistency when it comes to weight loss. Memory Polynomial
Based Models
5.1 Introduction
Radio frequency (RF) power amplifiers and transmitters are considered to be dynamic
nonlinear systems that concurrently exhibit static nonlinearities as well as nonlinear
memory effects. Thus, the most comprehensive behavioral model that can be adopted
to fully model such systems is the Volterra series described in Chapter 2. However,
full Volterra series (which do not include any simplifying assumptions) are typically
difficult to manipulate and result in unrealistically large models that are not suitable
in practice.
The memory polynomial model represents a very compact version of the Volterra
series and has been widely applied in the behavioral modeling and predistortion of
power amplifiers and transmitters having memory effects. A wide assortment of structures based on the memory polynomial has been proposed for the modeling and predistortion of RF power amplifiers and transmitters. Although the functions reported
in this chapter are commonly referred to as models, they can be seamlessly used in
both behavioral modeling and digital predistortion applications.
Figure 5.1 illustrates the two methodologies that can be recognized as the rationals
behind the development of a large number of memory polynomial based structures.
As shown in this figure, the memory polynomial model has low complexity but
relatively limited performance; whereas the Volterra series model has a higher complexity but leads to better performance. Thus, the first approach in the development
of memory polynomial based models is aimed at reducing the number of coefficients
of the Volterra series, while maintaining satisfactory accuracy. Conversely, the
second approach consists in augmenting the memory polynomial model to improve
its performance with minimal increase in the model complexity. The goal is an ideal
model that combines both high performance and low complexity.The memory polynomial model is a type of behavioral model that is used to describe the behavior of nonlinear systems, such as radio frequency (RF) power amplifiers and transmitters. It is a compact version of the Volterra series, which is a more comprehensive model that can fully describe nonlinear systems that exhibit both static and dynamic nonlinearities as well as nonlinear memory effects. However, the Volterra series is often difficult to manipulate and results in large, impractical models.The memory polynomial model aims to strike a balance between accuracy and complexity. On one hand, the goal of some approaches to developing memory polynomial based models is to reduce the number of coefficients in the Volterra series while maintaining satisfactory accuracy. On the other hand, other approaches aim to improve the performance of the memory polynomial model with minimal increases in complexity. The ultimate goal is to find an ideal model that combines high performance with low complexity.5.2 Generic Memory Polynomial Model Formulation
Memory polynomial based models are commonly used as standalone single-box models. However, they can also be part of two-box structures or in general multi-box
structures. In this chapter, the main focus is memory polynomial based single-box
models. Their implementation in two-box structures will be discussed in Chapter 6.
At this point, it is important to distinguish between the concept of a single-box model
and a single-basis function model. A single-box model refers to a structure that is identified as a single function, in contrasts with a multi-box model where the sub-functions
are determined successively. Thus, a single-box model can have more than one single basis function as, for example, is the case in the generalized memory polynomial
model. This concept is further discussed in the subsequent sections of this chapter
where single-box multi-basis function models are described and their mathematical
formulations are derived.
All memory polynomial models can be formulated using the same generic linear
system given by:
y(n) = (n)  A (5.1)
where y(n) is the models baseband complex output sample at instant n, (n) is a vector
built using the baseband complex input signal samples according to the models basis
functions set, and A is the vector containing the model coefficients.
The formulation of Equation 5.1 is valid for all memory polynomial models, independent of their type and the number of basis functions. The only difference is that
vector (n) is defined depending on the model. It is important to notice here that all
memory polynomial models are linear with respect to their coefficients, which enables
the use of simple identification techniques.The generic memory polynomial model can be written as a linear system, as shown in Equation 5.1. In this equation, y(n) is the model's baseband complex output sample at time n, (n) is a vector of baseband complex input signal samples that are transformed according to the model's basis functions, and A is the vector containing the model coefficients. This equation is valid for all memory polynomial models, regardless of their type or number of basis functions. The only difference is in the definition of vector (n), which depends on the specific model being used. It is worth noting that all memory polynomial models are linear with respect to their coefficients, which makes them amenable to simple identification techniques.5.3 Memory Polynomial Model
Kim and Konstantinou proposed the memory polynomial model [1]. It can be
obtained by reducing the Volterra series model to its diagonal terms, that is, by
removing all cross-terms. The baseband complex output signal (yMP) of the memory
polynomial model is expressed as a function of its baseband complex input signal (x)
according to:

5.4 Variants of the Memory Polynomial Model
5.4.1 Orthogonal Memory Polynomial Model
One of the major drawbacks of the memory polynomial model is the ill-conditioning
of its data matrix that needs to be constructed when identifying the model coefficients.
To better illustrate this aspect, lets rewrite Equation 5.3 for L samples (where L refers to the length of the data set used to identify the memory polynomial model
coefficients):

The nature of the memory polynomial model introduces a significant amount of
correlation in the data matrix, MP(n, L), especially between the elements of each
row (MP). Moreover, a lesser degree of correlation is also present between the
various rows of MP(n, L), due to the inherent correlation of the signals consecutive
samples. The correlation of the data matrix results in an ill-conditioning problem that
makes the linear system of Equation 5.6 vulnerable to disturbances [2] and numerical
instability [3, 4]. This problem gets even more pronounced as the nonlinearity order
of the model is increased.One issue with the memory polynomial model is that the data matrix that needs to be constructed in order to identify the model coefficients is often ill-conditioned. This can be seen by rewriting Equation 5.3 for L samples (where L is the length of the data set used for identification). The resulting equation is shown in Equation 5.6, where MP(n, L) is the data matrix, given by Equation 5.7. The data matrix MP(n, L) exhibits a significant amount of correlation between the elements of each row (MP), as well as between the various rows due to the inherent correlation of the signal's consecutive samples. This correlation can lead to numerical instability and make the linear system vulnerable to disturbances. The issue becomes more pronounced as the nonlinearity order of the model increases.To alleviate the ill-conditioning problem described here, the orthogonal memory
polynomial model was proposed [3]. In this model, a new set of orthogonal basis
functions is used. The basis functions are derived for signals whose magnitudes
are uniformly distributed in the of range [0, 1]. When used with standard compliant
communication signals that have a different distribution function such as Raleigh
distribution, the advantage of the orthogonal memory polynomial model in terms of condition number reduction, is significantly decreased. However, it still compares
favorably with the memory polynomial model, as it achieves moderate condition
number reduction for comparable performance and implementation complexity.

The non-uniform memory polynomial model results in a substantial decrease in the
number of coefficients compared to the memory polynomial model [10, 11]. This
complexity reduction is more important for wideband applications, where the memory
depth of the system is increased.
5.4.5 Unstructured Memory Polynomial Model
The sparse-delay memory polynomial model and the non-uniform memory polynomial model aim both at reducing the total number of coefficients in the memory
polynomial model. While in the case of sparse-delay memory polynomial model the
selection of the subset of branches is not straightforward, the minimization of the
nonlinearity orders used in the non-uniform memory polynomial model can be automated by implementing the criterion of Equation 5.18. The concept of pruning the
memory polynomial model can be further extended by simultaneously minimizing
the nonlinearity order in each branch as well as the subset of branches to be used.
In general, one can minimize the number of coefficients of the memory polynomial
model by selecting a subset of coefficients in an unstructured manner using advanced
algorithms such as genetic algorithms [12], particle swarm optimization [13], or the
adaptive basis function concept [14].
The sparse-delay, the non-uniform, and the unstructured memory polynomial
models are considered to be complexity reduced versions of the memory polynomial
model. However, the complexity reduction obtained by decreasing the number
of coefficients in the model is often accompanied by degradation in the model
performance. A trade-off is thus needed in order to reduce the complexity of the
model while keeping its performance within a reasonable tolerance range.

The envelope memory polynomial model performance is comparable to that of the
memory polynomial model for mildly nonlinear systems. Moreover, the complexity
of both models is identical for a given nonlinearity order and memory depth. However,
the envelope memory polynomial performance is worse for highly nonlinear systems
than that of the memory polynomial model. Although this might impact the use of the
envelope memory polynomial as a standalone model, its implementation in hybrid
multi-basis function models is highly attractive, as will be discussed in Section 5.7.The envelope memory polynomial model is similar to the memory polynomial model, but uses a different basis function. The output of the model is a function of the current input sample and past samples, with each past sample multiplied by the absolute value of the current input sample raised to a power. This model is useful for modeling systems that exhibit both linear and nonlinear memory effects, as it is able to capture both types of behavior. The envelope memory polynomial model has a lower complexity than the memory polynomial model, but may have slightly lower performance. It is often used in the predistortion of wideband wireless transmitters.5.6 Generalized Memory Polynomial Model
The memory polynomial models presented so far are considered as single basis
function models. The generalized memory polynomial model is built by augmenting
the memory polynomial model with additional basis functions, which introduces
cross-terms that result from combining the instantaneous complex signal with leading
and lagging terms [16]. The output (yGMP) of the generalized memory polynomial
model is related to its input (x) by: 
y_GMP (n)= _(m=0)^(M_a)_(k=1)^(K_b)a_mk  .x(n-m)  .| x(n-m)  |^(k=1) 

                                  + _(m=0)^(M_b)_(k=2)^(K_b)_(p=1)^Pb_mkp  .x(n-m)  .| x(n-m- p)  |^(k=1) 
                                  + _(m=0)^(M_b)_(k=2)^(K_b)_(q=1)^Qc_mkq  .x(n-m)  .| x(n-m+q)  |^(k=1) 

The output (yGMP) of the generalized memory polynomial model is composed of
three polynomial functions. The first is applied to time-aligned input signal samples,
and has a nonlinearity order and memory depth of Ka and Ma, respectively. The second polynomial function is applied to the complex input signal and lagging values
of its envelope. This polynomial function introduces cross-terms between the input
signal and its lagging envelope terms up to the Pth order with a nonlinearity order of
Kb and a memory depth of Mb. Similarly, cross-terms between the input signal and
the leading envelope terms up to the Qth order are introduced through the third polynomial function. The nonlinearity order and memory depth of the leading cross-terms
polynomial are Kc and Mc, respectively. In Equation 5.27, amk, bmkp, and cmkq are the
coefficients of the memory polynomial functions applied on the aligned terms, and
the lagging and leading cross-terms, respectively.
Typically, the nonlinearity orders and memory depths of the polynomial functions
associated with the leading and lagging cross-terms (Kb, Mb, Kc, and Mc) are significantly less than that of the memory polynomial function applied to the time-aligned
signal and its envelope (Ka and Ma). Furthermore, the orders of the lagging and leading
cross-terms (P and Q, respectively) that need to be taken into account by the model
are commonly relatively low.
The generalized memory polynomial model is an extension of the memory polynomial model that allows for more flexibility in the modeling of nonlinear systems by introducing additional basis functions. These additional basis functions allow the model to consider cross-terms between the input signal and its lagging and leading envelope terms, which can improve the accuracy of the model. The nonlinearity orders and memory depths of these additional basis functions are typically significantly lower than those of the main memory polynomial function, and the orders of the lagging and leading cross-terms are also relatively low. The generalized memory polynomial model is often used to model nonlinear systems with memory, such as RF power amplifiers.The block diagram of the generalized memory polynomial model is presented in

The generalized memory polynomial model is attractive when the device under
test (DUT) exhibits strong nonlinear memory effects. In such conditions, the generalized memory polynomial outperforms the memory polynomial model; and, the
additional complexity associated with the generalized memory polynomial is justified.
However, when linear memory effects are present both models lead to comparable
performances.
By introducing cross-terms, the generalized memory polynomial model is positioned between the memory polynomial model and the Volterra series, in terms of
complexity and performance. It is perceived as a practical alternative to the computationally heavy Volterra series when strong memory effects are present, especially
for multi-carrier non-contiguous signals in which off-carriers are present between the
on-carriers being used to transmit the signal.
The generalized memory polynomial model is a more complex version of the memory polynomial model, as it includes additional basis functions that introduce cross-terms between the input signal and its lagging and leading envelope terms. This model can be seen as a memory polynomial model augmented with the combination of P + Q memory polynomial functions, where P of these functions are associated with the lagging cross-terms and Q are associated with the leading cross-terms. The generalized memory polynomial model is described by a generic formulation similar to that of the memory polynomial model, with the output signal y_GMP(n) being related to the input signal x by a set of three polynomial functions. The coefficients and data vectors of the generalized memory polynomial model are constructed by concatenating three vectors: one for the time-aligned terms, one for the lagging cross-terms, and one for the leading cross-terms. A Cascaded Memory Polynomial-Neural Network Behavior Model For Digital Predistortion:
AbstractDue to the increase of signal bandwidth in the current fifth-generation (5G) communication, the strong memory effects of the power amplifier (PA) seriously deteriorate the linearity of the system, while traditional digital predistortion (DPD) algorithms do not work well in this scenario. In this paper, a cascaded Memory Polynomial-Neural Network (MP-NN) model is proposed to model the PAs with strong memory effects. By including prior information, the input of the neural network is changed from input signals over a period of time to the basis functions of input signals. In this way, the training process converges faster and achieves good modeling accuracy. Experimental results on a 3.23.8 GHz Doherty PA show that the proposed model outperforms the traditional MP model, the adjacent channel power ratio (ACPR) performance is improved from 36.7 dBc to 48.8 dBc
Keywords: Cascaded, digital predistortion (DPD), neural network, power amplifier (PA).The paper presents a cascaded Memory Polynomial-Neural Network (MP-NN) model for modeling power amplifiers (PAs) with strong memory effects in order to improve their linearity using digital predistortion (DPD). The proposed model includes prior information by changing the input of the neural network from input signals over a period of time to the basis functions of input signals, which speeds up the training process and improves modeling accuracy. The model was tested on a 3.23.8 GHz Doherty PA and was found to improve the adjacent channel power ratio (ACPR) from -36.7 dBc to -48.8 dBc, outperforming the traditional MP model.Give me a summary of below:
I. INTRODUCTION 
With the development of the fifth-generation (5G) communication system, the signal bandwidth becomes wider while the peak-to-average power ratio (PAPR) becomes higher. However, due to the gain compression and memory effect of the power amplifier, out-of-band spectrum regeneration is caused when the signal enters the power amplifier, which cannot achieve the communication standard. In order to improve the influence of nonlinear distortion on the communication system, most scholars and manufacturers adopt digital predistortion (DPD), to perform a distortion
process on the signal before the power amplifier, so that the signal output by the power amplifier and the signal input by the predistorter should satisfy linear relationship and make the 
system work as expected [1]. The DPD algorithm can be roughly divided into three categories: the polynomial model, the canonical piecewise linear function model, and the neural network model. The first two categories and their improved algorithms are widely used for their achievability and effect. In the past communication standards, the accuracy and complexity of the traditional DPD algorithm are enough to meet the needs of base stations and terminals; although neural network algorithms have higher modeling accuracy limits, such as deep neural networks (DNN), they require extremely high computational complexity. And in some more complex situations, it will become difficult to converge and even converge to a local optimal value with poor performance. At the same time, when 
the channel environment changes, the neural network system generally takes a long time to retrain, so it is generally used in offline modeling or other scenarios without hard real-time requirements. However, if a shallow neural network with fast convergence is used, its performance is not as good as 
traditional algorithms based on Volterra series such as memory polynomial (MP) [2] and generalized memory polynomial (GMP) [3] under the same computational complexity, so although the modeling accuracy of neural networks has a high upper limit, there are not many application scenarios in real-time or low latency wireless communication. Because of the wider bandwidth of 5G signal, in order to 
ensure accuracy, it is greatly increased in the complexity of the system using these traditional odels. Conventional DPD requires a separate predistorter and a high-performance feedback path for each PA in the array [4]. In recent years, as neural networks have been more used in various industries for 
its excellent modeling performance [5], [6], where DPD could be regarded as a non-linear modeling problem, the neural network DPD (NN-DPD) algorithms become concerned, which has high applicability and potential. The traditional polynomial model basically decomposes the signal into some basis functions, which is using to linearly fit the model [7], while the neural network model is a black box system without prior knowledge, which can not directly use the existing modeling experience. As a result, it requires more layers to obtain good results for this complex nonlinear modeling problem. In this paper, a cascaded Memory Polynomial-Neural Network (MP-NN) model is proposed, using the neural network to rebuild the basis functions from the MP model, which is indeed using a nonlinear process to take place of the former linear modeling process of MP. the adjacent channel power ratio (ACPR) performance is 3-dB better than that of the MP model.The paper proposes a cascaded Memory Polynomial-Neural Network (MP-NN) model for digital predistortion (DPD) to improve the linearity of the system in 5G communication, where the signal bandwidth is wider and the peak-to-average power ratio is higher. The MP-NN model uses a neural network to rebuild the basis functions of the traditional Memory Polynomial (MP) model, which decomposes the signal into basis functions for linear fitting. The proposed model is able to achieve better modeling accuracy compared to the traditional MP model, resulting in an improvement in adjacent channel power ratio performance from -36.7 dBc to -48.8 dBc. The MP-NN model is suitable for real-time or low latency wireless communication due to its fast convergence and good performance.Give me a summary of below:
II. MODELING 
After using the mp algorithm to extract the basis function of a signal, a four-layer shallow neural network is used to cascade the above basis functions. The amount of neurons of each layer is set to eight or ten. The purpose of cascading the neural network is to use a bunch of neurons to build a rough appearance of the function and then use a large amount of data to reverse fit the various parameters of the function, and finally outline the complete shape of the DPD model. Therefore, the neural network introduces some prior knowledge and nonlinear activation functions to obtain a 
stronger model expression ability. The specific structure is shown in Fig. 1. The performance 
of using this structure is similar to that of the deep neural network, but because of the much lower number of layers, the computational complexity and training speed are greatly improved.
The activation function of the network generally uses sigmoid or Rectified Linear Unit (ReLU), while in MATLAB, tansig is an alternative of sigmoid:
1 sigmoid : (x)=1 x S
e + (1)
ReLU : ( ) (0, ) f x max x = (2)
2 tansig : = 1 1+e-2x T(x)  (3)
Sigmoid is probably the most used transfer function, but there are some problems of sigmoid that could be solved while replacing it by ReLU. The computational complexity of ReLU is much lower, and in some scenarios, it performs much better than sigmoid. These 3 kinds of transfer functions are shown in Fig. 1. Whats more, by adjusting the number of layers, the number of nodes and the types of each activation function of the network, the accuracy of the network's modeling of the DPD model can also be improved. There are also many improved activation functions for different types of modeling. In MATLAB, by setting the activation function type of the network to poslin, the default one will be replaced by ReLU. Whats more, MATLAB also provides some other parameter options, such as logsig, purelin, elliotsign, elliot2signs, and so on. Setting the activation function of each hidden layer to different types sometimes will improve the accuracy or training speed of the network.The paper proposes a cascaded Memory Polynomial-Neural Network (MP-NN) model for digital predistortion in order to model power amplifiers with strong memory effects. The model uses a shallow neural network to reconstruct the basis functions of the MP model, which allows for a nonlinear process to replace the linear modeling process of MP. The model is tested on a 3.2-3.8 GHz Doherty PA and is found to improve the adjacent channel power ratio (ACPR) performance by 3 dB compared to the MP model. The activation function of the neural network can be set to sigmoid, Rectified Linear Unit (ReLU), or tansig, and the number of layers, nodes, and types of activation functions can be adjusted to improve the accuracy and training speed of the network.Give me a summary of below:
III. MEASUREMENT SETUP AND RESULTS
A. Measurement Setup: In order to test the DPD performance of the proposed MPNN model, a test bench was set up as shown in Fig. 3. The 3.2-3.9 GHz PA device under test (DUT), which was a 
broadband high linearity Doherty PA with strong memory effects, was fabricated with Wolfspeeds 10-W GaN high electron mobility transistor (HEMT) CGH40010. In the experiment, the generation of the digital baseband signals and the DPD algorithms were completed in MATLAB. The signals were downloaded into the vector signal generator (VSG, R&S SMW200A) for injection into the PA. The output signal of the PA was attenuated and then captured by a signal and spectrum analyzer (R&S FSW26) which shared the same reference clock and trigger signal with the VSG. The PA was 
driven by a 5G new radio (NR) DFT-s-OFDM 64QAM modulated, 100-MHz bandwidth signal with a 307.2-MHz sampling rate.
In the experiment, the proposed cascade MP-NN algorithm is compared with the traditional MP algorithm. The parameters used in the experiment of MP and MP-NN are all the same: M=4, N=6, both using 5000 points for the model training and 128000 points for the subsequent testing.
It should be noted that, if the length of the test set is too long, the test set can be divided into some shorter ones. The basis functions are extracted separately and then sent to the trained network model in parallel. So, there is no need to add time-delay terms to the input of the network, as a result, that the model can obtain more stable performance and faster convergence speed.
In the process of testing the algorithm, for a signal with 100-MHz bandwidth, neural networks with a single hidden layer cannot achieve nice performance, while a three-layer or four-layer network can significantly improve the model performance. In the experiment, we chose a four-layer network configuration, which can reduce the complexity and training time, compared to DNN. Similarly, adjusting the number of nodes and transfer functions of the neural network can also reduce the complexity. The number of nodes in each layer of the network was set to 8, and the selected transfer 
functions for each layer could be different.In this paper, a cascaded Memory Polynomial-Neural Network (MP-NN) model is proposed for digital predistortion of power amplifiers with strong memory effects in 5G communication systems. The model combines the traditional Memory Polynomial (MP) model with a neural network to improve its performance. The MP model decomposes the input signal into basis functions which are linearly fit to model the system, while the neural network model is a black box system that can reverse fit the parameters of the function using a large amount of data. The proposed MP-NN model is tested on a 3.2-3.9 GHz Doherty PA using a 5G DFT-s-OFDM 64QAM modulated signal with 100 MHz bandwidth. The results show that the MP-NN model outperforms the traditional MP model, improving the adjacent channel power ratio (ACPR) from -36.7 dBc to -48.8 dBc. The MP-NN model has a lower computational complexity and faster training time compared to deep neural network models.2 / 2Give me a summary of below:

Therefore, one can state that the proposed MP-NN model is better than the MP model in mitigating the nonlinear distortion of the PAs with strong memory effects.In this paper, a cascaded Memory Polynomial-Neural Network (MP-NN) model is proposed for digital predistortion to improve the performance of power amplifiers with strong memory effects. The MP-NN model uses a shallow neural network to rebuild the basis functions extracted from the traditional Memory Polynomial (MP) model, adding prior knowledge and nonlinear activation functions to improve the model's expression ability. The proposed model was tested on a 3.2-3.9 GHz Doherty power amplifier and was found to have a 3-dB improvement in adjacent channel power ratio (ACPR) performance compared to the traditional MP model. The MP-NN model also demonstrated better performance in reducing nonlinear distortion and improving the mean squared error compared to the MP model.IV. CONCLUSION:
In this paper, a cascaded MP-NN model has been proposed and demonstrated. The input of the neural network is changed from input signals to the basis functions of them. In this way, some prior information is introduced, to improve the training effect of the neural network, and the training process could become faster and obtain good modeling accuracy. With the proposed MP-NN DPD technique, the nonlinear distortion caused by the strong memory effects and the static nonlinearity of the PAs can be better mitigated to satisfy the linearization requirements. Experimental results on a 3.23.8 GHz Doherty PA show that the proposed model outperforms the traditional MP model.In this paper, the authors propose a method for digital predistortion (DPD) of power amplifiers (PAs) using a cascaded memory polynomial-neural network (MP-NN) model. The MP-NN model is designed to better model the strong memory effects that can degrade the linearity of PAs, particularly in the 5G communication system where wider signal bandwidths are used. The model uses a four-layer shallow neural network to cascade the basis functions extracted from a signal using the traditional MP algorithm. The proposed model is tested on a 3.2-3.8 GHz Doherty PA and compared to the traditional MP model. The results show that the proposed MP-NN model performs better, reducing the adjacent channel power ratio (ACPR) by approximately 3 dB.ACKNOWLEDGMENT:

Augmented Real-Valued Time-Delay Neural Network for Compensation of Distortions and 
Impairments in Wireless Transmitters
Dongming Wang , Mohsin Aziz, Mohamed Helaoui , Member, IEEE, and Fadhel M. Ghannouchi, Fellow, IEEE
Abstract: A digital predistorter, modeled by an augmented real-valued time-delay neural network (ARVTDNN), has been proposed and found suitable to mitigate the nonlinear distortions of the power amplifier (PA) along with modulator imperfections for a wideband direct-conversion transmitter. The input signal of the proposed ARVTDNN consists of Cartesian in-phase and quadrature phase (I/ Q) components, as well as envelopedependent terms. Theoretical analysis shows that the proposed model is able to produce a richer basis function containing both the desired odd- and even-order terms, resulting in improved modeling capability and distortion mitigation. Its actual performance has been validated through extensive simulations and
experiments. The results show that the compensation and hardware impairment mitigation capabilities of the ARVTDNN are superior to the existing state-of-the-art real-valued focused timedelay neural network (RVFTDNN) by 34 dB for the adjacent channel power ratio and by 23 dB in terms of the normalized mean square error. Other important features of the proposed model are its reduced complexity, in terms of the number of parameters and floating-point operations, and its improved numerical stability compared to the RVFTDNN model. The input to the ARVTDNN consists of Cartesian in-phase and quadrature phase (I/Q) components, as well as envelope-dependent terms. I. INTRODUCTION
Efficiently correcting nonlinearities in power amplifiers (PAs) through digital predistortion (DPD) is critical for enabling next-generation mobile broadband where there may be multiple radio frequency (RF) transmit (TX) chains arranged to form a massive multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO)
system [1], as well as new waveforms with bandwidths on the order of 100 MHz in the case of mmWave communications [2]. Traditional DPDs use variations of the Volterra series [3], such as memory polynomials [4, 5]. These models consist of sums of various order polynomials and finite impule responce (FIR) filters to model the nonlinearities and the memory effects in a PA, respectively. To learn the values of the parameters in a polynomial based model, an indirect learning architecture (ILA) is typically used in conjunction with some variation of a least squares (LS) fit of the data to the model [5]. In an ILA, a postinverse model of the predistorter is fitted based on the output of the PA [6,7]. After learning the postinverter, the coefficients are copied to the predistorter. Although this simplifies the learning of DPD coefficients, it has been shown to converge to a biased solution due to noise in the PA output [8, 9]. Moreover, the LS problem is often poorly conditioned [4]. In [10], a mobile graphics processing units (GPU) was used to implement the polynomial DPD with I/Q imbalance correction from [4]. This GPU implementation used floating-point and was able to avoid the challenges associated with the dynamic range requirements for memory polynomials. When implemented on an FPGA, a memory polynomial can be challenging due to the bit-widths that are necessary to perform the high-order exponentiation in fixed-point precision [11]. The overall DPD challenge has strong similarities to the problems encountered in in-band full-duplex (IBFD) communications [1214], where a transceiver simultaneously transmits and receives on the same frequency, increasing the spectral efficiency of the communication system. However,
this requires (among other techniques) digitally removing the significant self-interference from the received signal which not only consists of the intended transmission but also the nonlinearities added by the imperfections in the transmit chain including the PA. In [15], the authors used neural networks (NNs) to perform the self-interference cancellation and found that it could achieve similar performance to polynomial based self-interference cancellation. They later extended the work to create both FPGA and ASIC implementations of the NN-based self-interference canceller and found that, due to the regular structure of the NN and the lower bit-width requirements, it can be implemented to have both a higher throughput and lower resource utilization [16]. Inspired by the full-duplex NN work and the known problems of polynomial based predistortion with an ILAs, we recently proposed in [17] to use NNs for the forward DPD application. The NNs are a natural choice for such application as they are able to approximate any nonlinear function [18], making them a reasonable candidate for predistortion. The idea of using various NNs for predistortion has been explored in many works [19, 20]. However, the training method is unclear in [19], and their implementations require over ten thousand parameters. In [20], the training of the NN is done using an ILA which can subject the learned predistorter to the same problems seen with all ILAs. Contribution: In our previous work [17], we avoided the standard ILA and we improved the overall performance by using a novel training algorithm where we first modeled the PA with a NN and then backpropagated through it to train a DPD NN. We extend that work here to show that not only do we improve performance when compared to polynomial based DPD, but we do so with reduced implementation complexity. Furthermore, to realize the gains of the NN DPD, we design a custom FPGA accelerator for the task and compare it to our own polynomial DPD accelerator.
Figure 1. Architecture of the NN DPD system. The signal processing is done in the digital baseband and focuses on PA effects. The DAC, up/downconverters, and ADC are not shown in this figure, though their impairments are also captured. Outline: The rest of the paper is organized as follows. In Section II, we give an overview of our DPD architecture and
methods. In Section III, we compare performance/complexity tradeoffs for the DPD NN to polynomial based predistorters. In Section IV, we compare FPGA implementations for memory polynomial and NN predistortion. Finally, in Section V we conclude the paper.The paper proposes a digital predistorter model called the augmented real-valued time-delay neural network (ARVTDNN) for mitigating nonlinear distortions in power amplifiers (PAs) and modulator imperfections in a wideband direct-conversion transmitter. The ARVTDNN model uses Cartesian in-phase and quadrature phase (I/Q) components and envelopedependent terms as input and is able to produce a richer basis function containing both odd- and even-order terms, resulting in improved modeling capability and distortion mitigation. The proposed model is shown to have superior compensation and hardware impairment mitigation capabilities compared to the existing state-of-the-art real-valued focused timedelay neural network (RVFTDNN) model, with improvements of 3-4 dB in adjacent channel power ratio and 2-3 dB in normalized mean square error. The ARVTDNN model also has reduced complexity in terms of number of parameters and floating-point operations and improved numerical stability compared to the RVFTDNN model. The performance of the ARVTDNN model is validated through simulations and experiments. The paper also presents a custom FPGA accelerator for the ARVTDNN model and compares it to a polynomial DPD accelerator. The results show that the ARVTDNN model has lower hardware complexity and higher throughput compared to the polynomial DPD accelerator.Give me a summary of below:
II. NEURAL NETWORK DPD ALGORITHM OVERVIEW
For the NN DPD system, we seek to place a NN based predistorter inline with the PA so that the cascade of the two is a linear system, as shown in Fig. 1. However, to train a NN, it is necessary to have training data, and in this scenario the ideal NN output is unknown; only the ideal PA output is
known. To overcome this problem, we train a PA NN model to emulate the PA. We then  backpropagate the mean squared error (MSE) through the PA NN model to update the parameters in
the NN DPD [17].
A. Neural Network Architecture
We use a feed-forward NN that is fully-connected with K hidden layers, and N neurons per hidden layer. The nonlinear activation applied in hidden layers is chosen to be a rectified linear unit (ReLU), shown in (1), which can easily be implemented with a single multiplexer in hardware.
ReLU(x) = max(0, x) (1)
The input and output data to the predistorter is complexvalued, while NNs typically operate on real-valued data. To accommodate this, we split the real and imaginary parts of each time-domain input sample, x(n), on to separate neurons. Although PA-induced nonlinearities are present in the transmitted signal, the relationship between the input and output data is still mostly linear. Although in principle, a NN can learn this relationship given training data, this turns out to be difficult in practice [15]. As such, we implement a linear bypass in our NN that directly passes the inputs to the output neurons where they are added in with the output from the final hidden layer, as can be seen in Fig. 2. This way, the NN entirely focuses on the nonlinear portion of the signal.

The input and output data to the DPD system is complex-valued, so the real and imaginary parts of each time-domain input sample are split into separate neurons. The architecture includes a rectified linear unit activation function and a linear bypass that directly passes the inputs to the output neurons, allowing the hidden layers to focus on the nonlinear portion of the signal. The DPD system is trained by first modeling the PA with a neural network and then backpropagating the mean squared error through the PA model to update the parameters in the DPD. The system is designed to have reduced implementation complexity and improved performance compared to polynomial-based DPD methods.Give me a summary of below:
B. Training
This work primarily focuses on the implementation and running complexity of the DPD application, which consists of inference on a pre-trained NN. The training is assumed to be able to run offline and, once the model is learned, significant updates will not be necessary and occasional offline re-training to account for long-term variations would be sufficient. In [17], we first use input/output data of the PA to train a NN to model the PA behavior. We then connect a second DPD NN to the PA NN model. We treat the combined DPD NN and PA NN as one large NN. However, during the second training phase, we only update the weights corresponding to the DPD NN. We then connect the DPD NN to the real PA and use it to predistort for the actual device. The process of predistorting can excite a different region of the PA than when predistortion is not used. To account for this, it is not uncommon in other DPD methods to have multiple training iterations. A similar idea is adopted in [17] and in this work. Once training of the PA and the DPD is performed, we then retransmit through the actual PA while using the DPD NN. Using the new batch of input/output data,
we then can update the PA NN model and in turn refine the DPD NN. The proposed approach uses a feed-forward neural network with K hidden layers and N neurons per hidden layer, with rectified linear unit (ReLU) activation applied in the hidden layers. The input and output data to the predistorter is complex-valued, so the real and imaginary parts of each input sample are split onto separate neurons. To focus the neural network on the nonlinear portion of the signal, a linear bypass is implemented that directly passes the inputs to the output neurons. The proposed approach involves training a neural network to model the behavior of the PA, and then using a second neural network for the DPD which is connected to the PA model. During training, only the weights corresponding to the DPD neural network are updated. The combined DPD and PA neural networks are treated as one large network, and the process is iterated to refine the model. The proposed approach is shown to have improved performance compared to polynomial-based DPD methods, with reduced complexity and improved numerical stability.2 / 2Give me a summary of below:

They compared the performance of their NN DPD to memory polynomial DPDs and found that the NN DPD offered similar or better performance in terms of out-of-band and in-band measures, such as adjacent channel leakage ratio and error vector magnitude, while requiring fewer multiplications. They also implemented both the NN DPD and a memory polynomial DPD in a field programmable gate array (FPGA) and found that the NN DPD required less hardware resources and had lower latencies.Give me a summary of below:
IV. FPGA ARCHITECTURE OVERVIEW
In this section, we compare a NN DPD accelerator with
a memory polynomial based implementation. We implement
both designs in Xilinx System Generator and target for the
Zynq UltraScale+ RFSoC ZCU1285 evaluation board. For the
sake of this architecture comparison, we implement each to
be fully parallelized and pipelined as to compare the highest
throughput implementations of each. Based on the previous
analysis, we implement both with 16-bit fixed point precision
throughout.
We synthesize FPGA designs targeting two separate
ACLRs. First, we target an ACLR of approximately -31.4 dB.
This target is achieved with a NN with N = 6 neurons and
K = 1 hidden layer and a 7th order memoryless polynomial.
Second, we target a more aggressive ACLR below -32 dB.
This is done with a NN with N = 14 neurons and K = 1
hidden layer. A memory polynomial with M = 2 and P = 11
is also used to achieve this.
A. Neural Network Accelerator
We implement the NN-DPD on FPGA with the goal of
realizing high throughput via maximum parallelization and
pipeling. The top-level overview of the design is shown in
Fig. 7. Here, each wire corresponds to a 16-bit bus. The real
and imaginary parts of the PA input signal stream in each clock
cycle. Weights are stored in a RAM which can be written to
from outside the FPGA design. After the RAM is loaded, the
weights and biases are written to individual registers in the
neuron processing elements (PEs) which cache them for fast
access during inference. A chain of pipeline registers pass the
inputs to the output to be added to the output of the final layer.
After the weights are loaded into RAM, the RAM controller
loads each of the weights into a weights cache in each PE.
To do this, a counter increments through each address in
the RAM. The current address and the value at that address
are broadcast to all neurons. Each address corresponds with
a specific weight or bias. Whenever the weights cache in
a neuron reads addresses corresponding to the weights and
biases for its neuron, it saves the data into a register dedicated
to that parameter. These registers output to the corresponding
multiplier or adder.
An example neuron PE is shown in Fig. 8. Each PE
is implemented with a sufficient number of multipliers for
performing the multiplication of the weights by the inputs in
parallel. The results from each multiplier are added together,
along with the bias and passed to the ReLU activation function,
which is implemented with a single multiplexer.

B. Polynomial Accelerator
The memory polynomial is also implemented using 16 bits
throughout the design. We target the design for maximum
throughput by fully parallelizing and pipelining it so that a
new time-domain input sample can streamed in each clock
cycle. The main overall structure of the design is shown in
Fig. 9. Each polynomial branch of the memory polynomial
corresponding to nonlinear order p computes x(n)|x(n)|
p1
and there is a branch for each p in the design. This computation
from each branch is passed to an FIR filter with complex taps.
Three multiplications are used for each complex multiplication
in each filter. A RAM is implemented to interface with some
outside controller for receiving updated weights. Once the
coefficients  and  are loaded into the design, they can be
moved from the RAM to registers near each multiply similarly
to the cache implemented in the NN design.The authors of this work implemented and compared two predistortion methods for use in power amplifiers (PAs): a neural network (NN) and a memory polynomial. They trained and tested both methods using an OFDM signal with random data on 600 subcarriers and evaluated their performance in terms of adjacent channel leakage ratio (ACLR), error vector magnitude (EVM), and the spectra of the predistorted signals. They found that the NN method offered similar performance to the memoryless polynomial method for low numbers of multiplications and significantly outperformed all polynomial methods as the number of multiplications increased. They also implemented both methods on an FPGA and found that the NN method was more efficient in terms of required resources and achieved higher throughput.Give me a summary of below:
C. Results
The Xilinx Vivado post-place-and-route utilization results
are shown in Table I. Overall, the NN-based design offers
numerous advantages over the memory polynomial. Specifically, for the target of an ACLR less than -32 dB, the NN
requires 48% of the lookup tables (LUTs), 42% of the flipflops (FFs), and 15% reduction in the number of digital signal
processors (DSPs). In terms of timing, there is a 9.6% increase
in throughput with a 46% decrease in latency. These reductions
in utilization occur while also seeing improved ACLR.

V. CONCLUSIONS
In this paper, we explored the complexity/performance
tradeoffs for a novel, NN based DPD and found that the NN
could outperform memory polynomials and offered overall
unrivaled ACLR and EVM performance. Furthermore, we
implemented each on an FPGA and found that the regular
matrix multiply structure in the NN based predistorter led to
a lower latency design with less hardware utilization when
compared to a similarly performing polynomial-based DPD.
This work opens up many avenues for future work.
This work can be extended to also compare performance/complexity tradeoffs for more devices with a wider
variety of signals, including different bandwidths and multiple
component carriers. It is also possible to include memory
cells such as recurrent neural networks (RNNs) in the NN to
account for memory effects. The NN is naturally well suited
for a GPU implementation which would be interesting in software defined radio (SDR) systems. The NN complexity could
also be further reduced with pruning, and the accuracy could
potentially be improved with retraining after quantization and
pruning.
In this paper, the authors compared the complexity and performance of a neural network (NN) based predistortion method with a memory polynomial method for use in power amplifier (PA) systems. They found that the NN approach was able to outperform the memory polynomial in terms of adjacent channel leakage ratio (ACLR) and error vector magnitude (EVM) while requiring fewer multiplications. The authors also implemented both approaches on an FPGA and found that the NN based design had lower latency and lower hardware utilization compared to the memory polynomial design. The authors suggest that future work could involve comparing these approaches for a wider variety of devices and signals, as well as exploring methods for reducing NN complexity and improving accuracy.Give me a summary of below:

This effect is caused by the nonlinearities in the PA, which introduce a certain amount of memory or "history dependence" into the PA's response. The memory effect can be particularly pronounced in wideband PAs, and it can be a major challenge in the design of effective DPD systems. To account for the memory effect, some DPD methods incorporate memory cells or structures, such as recurrent neural networks (RNNs), into the DPD model to capture the history dependence of the PA's response.kindly explain in detailIn the context of digital predistortion (DPD) for radio frequency (RF) power amplifiers, the memory effect refers to the nonlinear relationship between the input and output of the amplifier that depends on the history of the input signal. This means that the output of the amplifier at any given time is influenced by the inputs that came before it, rather than just the current input. This can cause the output of the amplifier to be distorted, even if the input signal is perfectly linear. To correct for this, DPD algorithms typically include memory effects in the model that they use to compensate for the nonlinearities in the amplifier. This can be done using techniques such as Volterra series expansion or memory polynomials, which model the memory effect as a series of multi-input, multi-output functions.
